name: Muslim American Society of Greater LA
mission: TO MOVE PEOPLE TO STRIVE FOR GOD-CONSCIOUSNESS, LIBERTY AND JUSTICE, AND TO CONVEY ISLAM WITH UTMOST CLARITY
theoryOfChange: MAS states it focuses on the personal development of individuals through a comprehensive Islamic educational curriculum and promotes active involvement in communities across the U.S. through opportunities for community service, interfaith initiatives, youth programs, and civic engagement; it also states it moves people and nurtures life-long, God-centered agents of change to create a more just and virtuous society.

dimension_explanations.alignment: With a high donor fit and zakat-eligible status, the organization aligns closely with the religious and cultural urgency of the American Muslim community [2][6]. The mission focuses on liberty and justice, supported by a curriculum designed to address contemporary youth issues and spiritual growth [4][5].
dimension_explanations.impact: MAS LA demonstrates direct impact through its youth and advocacy programs, maintaining a program expense ratio of 77.3% [3]. While the organization reports a cost per beneficiary of approximately $124.45, the overall impact score of 36/50 reflects a need for more robust third-party verification and data transparency [1][4].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Muslim American Society of Greater LA empowers the local community through spiritual development, youth mentorship, and civic advocacy.
strengths: High program expense ratio of 77.3%, indicating a strong focus on direct service delivery
Exceptional fundraising efficiency with a cost of only $0.03 per $1 raised
Verified zakat-eligible status with clear policies on asnaf categories
baseline_narrative.summary: The Muslim American Society of Greater LA (MAS LA) is a religious non-profit dedicated to moving people toward God-consciousness and justice through clarity in conveying Islam [1][3]. The organization operates specialized programs including Tarbiya & Youth Ministry (TYM) and Public Advocacy & Civic Engagement (PACE) to foster leadership and social responsibility [4].

ideal_donor_profile.best_for_summary: Best for donors who prioritize local Southern California community building and want to support a lean, zakat-eligible organization with a long track record in youth tarbiya.
donor_motivations: Want to support local Los Angeles Muslim infrastructure
Value high financial efficiency with minimal overhead
Seek to fulfill zakat through religious and cultural advocacy
Trust established organizations with decades of local presence
giving_considerations: Operations are extremely lean with minimal administrative staff
Governance is concentrated in a very small board
Impact data is largely self-reported rather than externally audited
ideal_donor_profile.not_ideal_for: Donors who require large-scale international humanitarian relief or those who prioritize organizations with high-transparency ratings and large governing boards.

impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: Evidence ensures that spiritual and mentorship programs are effectively achieving their goals of community leadership.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: With <cite id="10">revenue growing at 120.8%</cite>, the organization is in a rapid growth phase and can absorb significant capital to expand its <cite id="4">youth and advocacy programs</cite>.

strengths.detail: The organization operates with a <cite id="6">77.3% program expense ratio</cite> and a remarkably low fundraising cost of <cite id="8">$0.03 per $1 raised</cite>.
With a history <cite id="1">dating back to 1993</cite>, MAS LA has over three decades of experience in <cite id="3">youth ministry and mentor development</cite>.
The charity has seen a <cite id="10">3-year revenue CAGR of 120.8%</cite>, indicating a significant expansion in community support.

strengths_deep_dive: MAS LA's strength lies in its ability to convert donor contributions directly into community programming. By maintaining a <cite id="6">77.3% program expense ratio</cite>, the organization ensures that funds are utilized for its core pillars, such as the <cite id="4">Mentor Development Program (MDP)</cite> and civic advocacy. This operational model is supported by <cite id="11">77.3% independent board members</cite>, providing a layer of oversight despite the organization's lean administrative structure. Furthermore, its <cite id="12">working capital of 3.6 months</cite> provides a stable buffer for its ongoing religious and cultural initiatives.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim American Society of Greater LA (MAS LA) is a community-focused religious non-profit that has been operating since <cite id="1">its founding in 1993</cite>. The organization's mission is to <cite id="2">convey Islam with utmost clarity</cite> while moving people toward God-consciousness and justice. MAS LA serves as a vital hub for the Southern California Muslim community, offering a diverse array of services ranging from <cite id="3">Tarbiya and Youth Ministry (TYM)</cite> to <cite id="4">Public Advocacy and Civic Engagement (PACE)</cite>. Financially, the organization demonstrated significant growth in the 2023 tax year, reporting <cite id="5">total revenue of $832,882</cite>. A defining characteristic of MAS LA's operations is its extreme leaness; the organization reported a <cite id="6">program expense ratio of 77.3%</cite> in its most recent filings, suggesting that nearly all contributions are directed toward service delivery. Furthermore, the charity maintains <cite id="7">exceptional fundraising efficiency</cite>, spending only <cite id="8">$0.03 to raise every $1</cite> in donations. This efficiency, combined with its <cite id="9">verified zakat-eligible status</cite>, makes it a prominent choice for local donors seeking to fulfill religious obligations through community-based spiritual and social development.
